instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00875: What is 820-00875? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.AVREF_SMC: What is AVREF_SMC? AVREF_SMC is a reference voltage provided to the SMC so that its sensors have a reference to work from, this should be 3.3v.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.D6905: What is D6905? Diode sitting between PPBUS_G3H/PP18V5 charger voltage and PP3V42_G3H power supply input on very old Macbooks(before 2011), can die and cause PP3V42_G3H to be missing and have no input voltage. .
definitions.D6990: What is D6990? Diode sitting between PPBUS_G3H/PP18V5 charger voltage and PP3V42_G3H power supply input, can die and cause PP3V42_G3H to be missing and have no input voltage. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> boosting after liquid damage
threads.message:
Hi, I have a 00875 thats had liquid damage over the <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> side of the board. 

After going through the UC, the laptop started from the battery and got into the OS but I walked away and came back to it turned off.  Not sure if the battery is drained or something else.
I don't have a spare battery to test with.

20.4v going into the board from the genuine charger.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is boosting to 12.93v and then dropping to 3.4v repeatedly
<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is boosting to 5.1v then drops to 3.2v and then drops to 0v.. it then starts over again.

I get a fan twitch and the CPU is getting warm

Apologies if I should have given some basic info that I've missed in this initial post.

Any help would be appreciated

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> boosting after liquid damage
threads.message: Try to start in SMC bypass mode first.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> boosting after liquid damage
threads.message: Hi 2informaticos.. holding down the power for smc bypass doesn't seem to do anything different

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> boosting after liquid damage
threads.message: I lied.. it just did smc bypass and started

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> boosting after liquid damage
threads.message:
Start then in SMC bypass mode and check all power sensors output, pages 43-45.
Be sure first to have correct <SIGNAL>AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL> voltage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> boosting after liquid damage
threads.message: It turns itself off after a few seconds. Gets into the OS but thats about it before the power cuts off

threads.message: When it cuts power, the DCIN drops to 5.2v 0.02a

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> boosting after liquid damage
threads.message: SMC bypass doesnt seem to work either now. Fan spins full for about 2 seconds but nothing more and no screen.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> boosting after liquid damage
threads.message:
Try UC again.
You can check one power sensor every time the machine turns on.
2s should be enough for one reading; no need to login to OSX.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> boosting after liquid damage
threads.message:
<CAPACITOR>C5409</CAPACITOR> <SIGNAL>SMC_CPU_HI_ISENSE</SIGNAL> = 30MV

<CAPACITOR>C5680</CAPACITOR> <SIGNAL>SMC_CPU_VSENSE</SIGNAL> = 0.5-0.9 BOOSTING

<CAPACITOR>C5605</CAPACITOR> <SIGNAL>SMC_CPU_ISENSE</SIGNAL> = 0V

<CAPACITOR>C5615</CAPACITOR> <SIGNAL>SMC_GT_ISENSE</SIGNAL> = 135MV

<CAPACITOR>C5682</CAPACITOR> <SIGNAL>SMC_GT_VSENSE</SIGNAL> = 0MV

<CAPACITOR>C5691</CAPACITOR> <SIGNAL>SMC_SA_IMON_ISENSE</SIGNAL> = 359MV

<CAPACITOR>C5631</CAPACITOR> <SIGNAL>SMC_SA_ISENSE</SIGNAL> = 0MV

<CAPACITOR>C5523</CAPACITOR> <SIGNAL>SNC_3V3S5_ISENSE</SIGNAL> = 0.5V

<CAPACITOR>C5518</CAPACITOR> <SIGNAL>SMC_3V3SSD_ISENSE</SIGNAL> = 0MV




<CAPACITOR>C5690</CAPACITOR> - <SIGNAL>SMC_CPU_IMON_ISENSE</SIGNAL> = 0V

<CAPACITOR>C5469</CAPACITOR> <SIGNAL>SMC_TPAD_ISENSE</SIGNAL> = 0V

<CAPACITOR>C5508</CAPACITOR> <SIGNAL>SMC_1V2S3_ISENSE</SIGNAL> = 0V

<RESISTOR>R5489</RESISTOR> <SIGNAL>SMC_PBUS_VSENSE</SIGNAL> = 2.1V

<CAPACITOR>C5489</CAPACITOR> <SIGNAL>SMC_PBUS_VSENSE</SIGNAL> = 2.1V

<CAPACITOR>C5438</CAPACITOR> <SIGNAL>SMC_BMON_ISENSE</SIGNAL> = 0V

<CAPACITOR>C5533</CAPACITOR> <SIGNAL>SMC_3V3WLS_ISENSE</SIGNAL> 0V

<CAPACITOR>C5459</CAPACITOR> <SIGNAL>SMC_LCDBKLT_ISENSE</SIGNAL> = 0V

<CAPACITOR>C5528</CAPACITOR> <SIGNAL>SMC_3V3LCD_ISENSE</SIGNAL> = 0V

Hopefully theres something here that looks odd

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> boosting after liquid damage
threads.message:
There should be broken trace, or solder.

Try good flux and heat SMC and CPU.
This will not solve broken trace, but give it a try.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> boosting after liquid damage
threads.message: I'll flux and heat the SMC with 559 flux and give the cpu a little heat without flux (I'm assuming you didn't mean flux the CPU also)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> boosting after liquid damage

Puff, liquid spill close to backlight output; that's big danger for the new boards :(
Supposedly problem with USB-C controllers...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> boosting after liquid damage
threads.message: Yeah that's quite a bit of liquid damage. Do you get 5 volts on DC in for both ports currently? How do the chargeports look currently badly burned or OK?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> boosting after liquid damage
threads.message:
I get 5.2v on both ports. The charge ports look perfect, all the fuzzy coating came off in the UC and no pins etc are burnt or tarnished.

Any ideas?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> boosting after liquid damage
threads.message: Ok is <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> present, slightly low, or missing? Being there was liquid near the CD3215s I would not surprised if they are an issue.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> boosting after liquid damage
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> isn't present on charger (expected) or on battery. Both show 0.0v

Its near on impossible for me to test around <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> on battery but on the charger I get 5.2v on <DIODE>D6905</DIODE> pin 2 5.1v on pin 3
On <DIODE>D6990</DIODE>, I get 5.1v on pin 2 but 0.0v on pin 10 enable.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> boosting after liquid damage
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> enable comes from <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.
As SMC requires this voltage, problem should be on <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area, not on USB-C controllers, nor SMC.
Cannot have communication between them, without <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> boosting after liquid damage
threads.message:
Pin 27 on <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is a direct connection to Pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R6991</RESISTOR> from what I can tell.
As I'm not getting anything on <RESISTOR>R6991</RESISTOR> I wanted to look at <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> to see if it is even getting the voltages it needs, but I'm not good enough at understanding the schematic just yet.

Could someone better than me let me know what voltages I need around <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> to feed <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> please. That way I can see if it needs replacing or its something feeding it thats is the issue.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> boosting after liquid damage
threads.message: Check basic voltages on <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>; <SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL>, VDDA/P, <SIGNAL>AUX_OK</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> boosting after liquid damage
threads.message:
Thank you 2informaticos.. 

Pin 10 - <SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL> = 5.16v
Pin 18 - <SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL> = 1.28v
Pin 2 - VDDA = 1.39v
Pin 17 - VDDP = 1.39v
Pin 28 - <SIGNAL>SMC_AUX_OK</SIGNAL> = 0.0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> boosting after liquid damage
threads.message:
Pin 2 - VDDA = 1.39v
Pin 17 - VDDP = 1.39v
Change <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> boosting after liquid damage
threads.message: Okay.. I'll give that a go.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> boosting after liquid damage
threads.message: What should VDDA and VDDP be showing as? I'm assuming <SIGNAL>SMC_AUX_OK</SIGNAL> should be outputting something also but it looks like that needs 3v3 too

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> boosting after liquid damage
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7000</CHIP> requires (internally generated) 5V to work.
And is not present in your case...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> boosting after liquid damage
threads.message: Now to find a UK supplier of the chip :p

I can?t get it to start in SMC bypass either, I just get a fast fan for 2 seconds and it goes off again

threads.message: Ive taken F7000 off the board to see if <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> fluctuates on the pin one side of the fuse when its not continuing on to the system. Its still fluctuating but not as much (or my meter can't see it) it looks like its going from 7v to 12.95v repeatedly

threads.message:
You must get stable <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> when F7000 is removed (pad 1).
If not, check other volyages for <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> boosting after liquid damage
threads.message:
VDDA Pin 2 - 5.02v
VDDP Pin 17 - 5.02v

PPDCIN Pin 10 - 20.2v
<SIGNAL>TBA_CSIR_N</SIGNAL> Pin 15 - 20.2v
<SIGNAL>TBA_CSIR_P</SIGNAL> Pin 20 - 20.2v

<SIGNAL>TBA_AUX_DET</SIGNAL> Pin 18 - 5.01v
<SIGNAL>SMC_AUX_OK</SIGNAL> Pin 28 - 3.396v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> boosting after liquid damage
threads.message:
LX1 Pin 31 is fluctuating between 0v and 36mv
LX2 Pin 6 is also doing the same

Thats only with a multimeter though so it may be jumping higher but its too quick to catch

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> boosting after liquid damage
threads.message:
3V42 and <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> stable high?
Check for any moved component around <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.
<RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> gets steady 20V?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> boosting after liquid damage
threads.message:
If you mean <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> on pin 30, that is stable at 3.396v
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is also stable at 3.396v

I can't see anything wrong around <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>

<RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> is a stable 20.2v on both sides

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> boosting after liquid damage
threads.message:
I started testing all caps and resistors on the PBUS side between <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and F7000, found <RESISTOR>R7062</RESISTOR> (which should be a 1ohm 0201 resistor reading as 147ohms so <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> probably thought there was a ton of drain with that at 147ohm.

Swapped <RESISTOR>R7062</RESISTOR> out and now I have a solid 12.95v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> up to F7000

Now to reattach the fuse and cross my fingers :)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> boosting after liquid damage
threads.message: Damn it.. I get noise to say the charger is plugged in and an apple logo for 1 second :mad:

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> boosting after liquid damage
threads.message:
Seems the keyboard is interfering. If I disconnect the keyboard, it turns on fine and stays on. Power button held on maybe.

Anyone know what to short to trigger the equivalent of pressing the power button? I don't have a spare keyboard for this model.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> boosting after liquid damage
threads.message:
Shorting pin 4 and 5 on the keyboard connector doesnt seem to work nor does shorting pin 1 of the non existent SW9988

Edit: For anyone else reading this, SW9988 pin 1 doesn't seem to have its pad connected to <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> so it doesnt work as a replacement for a power button when shorted to ground. Use pin 5 on the keyboard connector instead.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> boosting after liquid damage
threads.message:
Actually it does work when I short pin 5 to ground.. new keyboard it is then

[USER="682"]2informaticos[/USER] Thank you for your help
